Retweeting for better visibility for everyone who was asleep when I posted this last night.

The NFT Billboard Token is up for auction for 3 days (2.5 now), starting at 0.1 ETH. All proceeds will go to @reli3fxyz to help with humanitarian efforts in Ukraine. https://t.co/xHjiyGwxW1
@MargaretLabour I'm sorry lorepunk. Thinking of you and your family ‚ô•Ô∏è
@iamDCinvestor @reli3fxyz They are working directly with organizations in Ukraine, so it's not like contributing to the Red Cross where you're money might be spent elsewhere around the globe.

@iamDCinvestor I've been impressed with @reli3fxyz's due diligence
https://t.co/OdD3j86DIc

@Zeneca_33 While tacky to jump into a thread and shill another project, but I literally just started an auction where 100% of the proceeds with go to Ukraine, and the art is... comparable to Kevin?
https://t.co/xHjiyGwxW1

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang Thank you to everyone who has donated their time and/or money thus far to assist the people of Ukraine. There are some people in this space with tremendous hearts. The internet of value has unlocked the ability for us to do incredible things together.

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang I still wanted to contribute in a meaningful way. Could I eek out enough time to build something small?

Then I remembered I had the NFT Billboard in my back pocket! I found the time to reword some text on the webpage, and now the auction can begin.

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang When Russia invaded Ukraine I knew that Web3 could be used to help the people of Ukraine in a big way, but I did not have the bandwidth to build anything...

I breathed a sigh of relief (reli3f) when I saw Andrew's tweet and the quick response.

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang So I would need to look for a new charity. But I had ideas for other things to build that I'd focus on first...

Then things with my day job got busy, and things in my personal life even more so. Several weeks went buy where I didn't get my IDE open.

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang There was nothing educational about the NFT Billboard, so it would have to fill its purpose via charity, and why not start out with a bang and donate 100%?

I had a charity in mind. I reached out. They said thanks but no thanks. They were anti-NFT.

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang Sylph Dapps was born, and the NFT Billboard was brought under its umbrella.

https://t.co/oFzikCX1UR

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang I would do my part to counteract these turns offs by having everything I created going forward either teach about web3 or have part of its proceeds go to charity (or both).

I would show people that the learning curve wasn't that bad and that real good can be done with crypto.

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang Alas, my following at launch was zero, and my skills are not in marketing. The few people I awkwardly reached out to about it didn't respond to me. Knowing more now, I went about it all wrong.

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang When I launched it last April, I had hoped it would become something everyone in the NFT space would talk about.

Who would be the buyer? A DAO? A private company with .eth in their handle?

What would they post?

Would they ever sell?

@reli3fxyz @andrwwang On the NFT Billboard Token: It is an NFT that gives the owner the ability to edit the message on the billboard on https://t.co/ACZ5JdqKn8.

Messages on the billboard are stored on-chain, forming a permanent history of all the owners and their messages to the world.
@reli3fxyz @andrwwang No matter how much money this auction raises, I feel comfortable knowing that Reli3f will responsibly deploy it where it can make the biggest impact for the people of Ukraine.

@reli3fxyz On Reli3f: I've been following Reli3f's work closely since @andrwwang's call to action.

https://t.co/u88l68djhr

@reli3fxyz Getting the right people's eyes on this auction could make a material difference for people living in Ukraine.

I know it's tacky to ask, but if you can see this, consider being liberal with the retweet button.

Two months ago I pledged to auction off the NFT Billboard Token for charity.

I can think of no better time than now and no better recipient than @reli3fxyz.

The auction starts now and will run for 72 hours.

https://t.co/RlwLvCUrHa https://t.co/Du6AnOsp9j

@runasand @JacopoMalensek Yes, the Russian govt would have trouble getting data from exchanges that don't operate under their purview, but that shifts the claim that donations are hard to track from a property inherent to crypto to a property of the policies of each exchange.

@runasand @JacopoMalensek Honestly the hardest part will be getting the addresses from the Russian exchanges because it involves coordinating with other humans, but if you want to track people who donated directly from a bank account you have to do that step, too.

@runasand @JacopoMalensek Export the addresses to CSV and cross-ref that with addresses from Russian exchanges and you've got names. A little harder if people have withdrawn their crypto to a separate address but they can be linked up again with an npm lib.

@runasand @JacopoMalensek I'm not trying to be rude, but you might want to consider deleting your first tweet. People are less likely to see your follow ups, and the misinfo (albeit unintended) could end up really hurting some people.

@runasand @JacopoMalensek Yes it is less controllable, but it is easy to track with no special resources to set up.

You can go to the donation address on Etherscan and see all the addresses that donated.
@tmagled @andrwwang Can you explain what you *did* do that led to you thinking you'd done something wrong? Seems there is room for a UX improvement.

@andrwwang The contract owner, which is a single external address, can withdraw to any address. Please have him withdraw to a multisig. Not saying I don't trust the dev, but a single compromised/lost key could ruin this whole thing.

32 hrs after @andrwwang's "how can we help?" tweet, @reli3fxyz opened minting and raised over a $1m in 30 secs, all of which will help the people of Ukraine.

@iKOR_OG @opensea Nope. The thief collected signatures from users over the last 30 days and most likely exercised them last night because they were running out of time since the OS contract migration would have made them useless.

X2Y2's airdrop timing was an unlucky coincidence it would seem.
@illycryptokid @iKOR_OG @opensea A new NFT exchange that launched in the last week or so

@Ninja_crypto_ @opensea The issue was users gave token approvals to a contract/site thinking it was OpenSea. Leaving OpenSea approvals in place should be safe, but you'll want to make sure they are in fact OpenSea.
@tayvano_ Remember the time before flash loans? Things were so much less weird.

The tech will get better while we build during the bear. More people will come with the bull.

The adversity is not going to go away unfortunately. The goal is global adoption, so this space will eventually be indistinguishable from anywhere else.

I believe more people are leaving because the prices have tanked than anything to do with web3 itself.

I'm sure there are some who have been turned off by adversity in certain communities or by cumbersome tech, but the majority have left because they are out $

... of them going is that things are going to calm down.

Think of it like sending the kids off to school.

You're happy for some peace and quiet. You don't love them any less, and eventually look forward to them coming home.

I can't reply because you don't follow me so a quote tweet will have to do.

I've been through a few cycles. The bull part can get exhausting. The bear part is quiet and when we get a lot of building done.

@PixlitEth I don't think this sheds any light on a debate between centralization vs decentralization. Rather it shows we need better education wrt tech literacy now that people are self custody-ing. Knowing how to spot phishing and not sign random messages would have saved people here.

@0xQuit and @0xfoobar have a good understanding of what's happening with the OpenSea hack and are talking in this space:
https://t.co/LwGNdeUBxl
@JacobOracle @DirectorJayC More info is coming to light and the phishing email explanation is holding water.
@econoar The site the hacker would have set up would have had the user connect their wallet in order to sign, in which case they'd have their address, too.
@andrwwang Correct. The timing is just coincidence. Purely OpenSea + phishing
Revoking approvals also works, but the usual revoke sites are down. @0xQuit is putting together instructions on how to do this from the contract UI.

Distilling info from various people:

- Hacker likely sent a phishing email to collect sigs from OpenSea users over the course of a month
- Hacker waited until now to act because the contract migration would render the sigs useless
- Moving NFTs to new wallet protects you
@econoar This all tracks. And Saturday night of ETH Denver was the last best chance to strike.

@andrwwang That tracks actually. The hacker could have been collecting approvals for days/weeks and waiting for the best time to strike to maximize their take. OpenSea migration forced them to act or miss out entirely. Saturday night of ETH Denver would be the last best chance.
